title: 110_hr3851
content:
The "Non-Citizen Enforcement Act of 2007" includes provisions such as increased border patrol agents, powers for State officers, penalties for unlawful presence, and assistance programs for criminal aliens. The Act aims to address issues related to illegal immigration and border security. The "Non-Citizen Enforcement Act of 2007" includes provisions for increasing the number of full-time active-duty border patrol agents by at least 2,000 each fiscal year until effective control of the border is achieved. The Secretary of Homeland Security must certify this control through the Secure Border Initiative and provide details on recruitment incentives, retention plans, and methodology used for assessment. SEC. 3. POWERS OF STATE OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES: State officers and employees are authorized to arrest aliens unlawfully present in the US who have been ordered removed in absentia, coordinating with Homeland Security for transportation and detention.

SEC. 4. LISTING ON NCIC OF ALIENS ORDERED REMOVED IN ABSENTIA. SEC. 4. LISTING ON NCIC OF ALIENS ORDERED REMOVED IN ABSENTIA: Aliens ordered removed in absentia will have their names posted on the Absconder Category of the National Criminal Information Center database if a motion to reopen the order is not filed within 180 days. SEC. 5. PENALTIES FOR ALIENS UNLAWFULLY PRESENT IN THE UNITED STATES. Amends Section 275 of the Immigration and Nationality Act to include penalties for aliens present in the US in violation of immigration laws. SEC. 6. Increase in funding for State Criminal Alien Assistance Program (SCAAP) to $1.5 billion. Clarification that funds can be used for transportation and related costs. SEC. 7. Increased penalties for certain crimes by illegal aliens. SEC. 7. Increased penalties for certain crimes by illegal aliens include harsher punishments for possession of firearms and distribution of controlled substances by aliens not lawfully in the country. Possession of firearms can result in a maximum 20-year imprisonment, while distribution of controlled substances can lead to twice the maximum imprisonment provided by the Controlled Substances Act. SEC. 8. Increased penalties for smuggling previously deported aliens include a maximum 20-year imprisonment if the alien has a criminal conviction in the National Crime Information Center.
